The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. div.p:
AWay to the Ea≈øt India's being lately di≈øcovered by Sea, to the South of Affrick by certain Portugals, far more ≈øafe and profitable then had been heretofore; certain Engli≈øh Merchants encouraged by the great advantages ari≈øing from the Ea≈øtern commodities, to ≈øettle a Factory there for the advantage of Trade. And having to that purpo≈øe obtained the Queens Royal Licence Anno Dom. 1589. 11. or 12. Eliz. furni≈øht out of tho≈øe parts four Ships, my Ma≈øter being ≈øent as Factor to deal and Negotiate for them, and to ≈øettle there, took with him his whole Family, (that is to ≈øay) his Wife, and one ≈øon of about twelve years of age, one daughter of about fourteen years, two maid ≈øervants, one Negro female ≈ølave, and my ≈øelf, who went under him as his Book-keeper, with this company on Monday the
third of April next following; (having all nece≈ø≈øaries for Hou≈øe-keeping when we ≈øhould come there, we emberqued our ≈øelves in the good ≈øhip called the India Merchant, of about four hundred and fifty Tuns burthen, and having a go it wind, we on the fourteenth of May had ≈øight of the Canaries and not long after of the I≈øles of Cape Vert or Verd, where taking in ≈øuch things as were nece≈ø≈øary for our Voyage, and ≈øome fre≈øh Previ≈øions we ≈øtearing our cour≈øe South, and a point Ea≈øt, about the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt came within ≈øight of the I≈øland of St. Hellen, where we took in ≈øome fre≈øh water, we then ≈øet our forces for the Cape of good Hope, where by Gods ble≈øsing after ≈øome ≈øickne≈ø≈ø, whereof ≈øome of our Company died, though none of our Family: and hitherto we had met with none but calm weather, yet ≈øo it plea≈øed God, when wer were almo≈øt in ≈øight of St. Laurence an I≈øtand ≈øo called, one of the greate≈øt in the world, as Mr. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ overtaken and di≈øper≈øed by a great ≈øtorm of wind, which continued, with ≈øuch violence many dayes, that loo≈øing all hopes of ≈øafety, being out of our own knowledge, and whether we ≈øhould fall on Falts or Ricks, uncertain in the night, not having the lea≈øt benefit of the light, we feared mo≈øt, always wi≈øhing for day, and then for Land, cut it come too ≈øoon for our good; for about the fir≈øt of October, our fears having made us forget how the time pa≈ø≈øed to a certainty; we about the break of day di≈øcerned Land (but what we knew not) the Land ≈øeemed high and Rockey, and the See continued ≈øtill very ≈øtorney and tempe≈øtuous, in≈øomuch as there, ≈øeemed no hope of ≈øafety, but looked ≈øuddenly by to peri≈øh. As we grew near Land, perceiving no, ≈øafely in the ≈øhip which we looked would ≈øuddenly be beat in pieces: The Captain my Ma≈øter, and ≈øome others got into the long Boat, thinking by that means to ≈øave their lives, and pre≈øently after all the Seamen ca≈øt them≈øelves overboard, thinking to ≈øave their lives by ≈øwimming, onely my Self, my Ma≈øters Daughter, the two Maids, and the Negro were left on board, for we could not ≈øwim; but tho≈øe that left us, might as well have carried with us, for we ≈øaw them, or mo≈øt of them peri≈øh, our Selves now ready after to follow their fortune, but God was plea≈øed to ≈øpare our lives, as it were by
miracle, though to further ≈øorrow; for when we come again≈øt the Rocks, our Ship having endured two or three blows again≈øt the Rocks, (being now broken and quite foundred in the Waters, we having with much ado gotten our ≈øelves on the Bow≈øpright, which being broken off, was driven by the Waves into a ≈ømall Creek, wherein fell a little River, which being encompa≈ø≈øed by the Rocks, was ≈øheltred from the wind ≈øo that we had opportunity to land our ≈øelves, (though almo≈øt drowned) in all four per≈øon, be≈øides the Negro; When we were got upon the Rocks, we could perceive the mi≈øerable wrack to our great terrour, I had in my Pocket a little Tinder-box, and Steel, and Flint to ≈øtrike fire at any time upon occa≈øion, which ≈øerved now to good purpo≈øe, for its being ≈øo clo≈øe, pre≈øerved the Tinder dry; with this, and the help of ≈øome old Rotten Wood which we got together, we kindled a Fire and dryed our ≈øelves, which done, I left my Female company, and went to ≈øee, if I could find any of our Ships company, that were e≈øcaped, but could hear of none, though I hooted, and made all the noi≈øe I could; neither could I perceive the foot≈øteps of any living Creature (≈øave a few Birds, and other Bowls. At length it drawing towards the Evening I went back to my company, who were very much troubled for want of me. I being now all their ≈øtay in this lo≈øt condition; we were at fir≈øt affraid that the wild people of the Countrey might find us out, although we ≈øaw no foot≈øteps of any, no not ≈øo much as a Path; the Woods round about being fult of Briers and Bramble, we al≈øo ≈øtood in fear of wild Bea≈øts, of ≈øuch al≈øo we ≈øaw none, nor ≈øign of any: But abve all, that we had greate≈øt rea≈øon to fear, was to be ≈øtarved to death for want of Food, but God had otherwi≈øe provided for us, as you ≈øhall know hereafter; this done; we ≈øpent our time in getting ≈øome broken pieces of Board and Planks, and ≈øome of the Sails an Rigging on Shoar for ≈øhelter; I ≈øet up two or three Poles, an drew two or three of the Cords and Line from Tree to Tree, over which throwing ≈øome Sailcloathes and having gotten Wood by us, and three or four Sea g ‚Ä¢ wns which we had dryed, we took up our lodging for „Äà‚óä„Äâ night altogether (the Blackmore being le≈øs ≈øen≈øible then
the re≈øt we made our Centry, we ≈ølept ≈øoundly that night, as having not ≈ølept in three or four nights before (our fears of what happened preventing us) neither could our hard lodging, fear, and danger hinder us, we were ≈øo overwatcht.

On the morrow, being well refre≈øht with ≈øleep, the wind cea≈øed, and the weather was very warm; we went down the Rocks on the Sands at low Water, where we found great part of our lading, either on ≈øhore or floating near it. I by the help of my company, dragged mo≈øt of it on ≈øhore; what was too heavy for us we broke, and unbound the Casks and Che≈øts, and, taking out the goods, ≈øecured all; ≈øo that we wanted no clothes, nor any other provi≈øion nece≈ø≈øary for Hou≈øekeeping, to furni≈øh a better Hou≈øe than any we were like to have; but no Victuals (the ≈øalt Water having ≈øpoiled all) onely one Cask of Bisket, being lighter than the re≈øt was dry; this ≈øerved for Bread a while, and we found no Land a ≈øort of fowl about the bigne≈ø≈øe of a Swan, very heavy and fat, that by rea≈øon of their weight could not fly, of the≈øe we found little difficulty to kill, ≈øo that they were our pre≈øent food; we carried out of England certain Hens and Cocks to eat by the way, ≈øome of the≈øe when the Ship was broken, by ≈øome means got to Land, and bred exceedingly, ≈øo that in the future they were a great help unto us; we found al≈øo, by a little River, in the flags, ≈øtore of eggs, of a ≈øort of fowl much like our Ducks, which were very good meat, ≈øo that we wanted nothing to keep us alive.

On the morrow, which was the third day, as ≈øoon as it was morning, ≈øeeing nothing to di≈øturb us, I lookt out a convenient place to dwell in, that we might build us a Hut to ≈øhelter us from the weather, and from any other danger of annoyance, from wild Bea≈øts (if any ≈øhould find us out): So clo≈ø≈øe by a large Spring which ro≈øe out of a high hill over looking the Sea; on the ≈øide of a Wood, having a pro≈øpect towards the Sea (by the help of an Ax and ≈øome other implements, for we had all nece≈ø≈øaries, the working of the Sea, having ca≈øt up mo≈øt of our goods) I cut down all the ≈øtreighte≈øt poles I could find, and which were enough for my purpo≈øe, by the help of my company, (nece≈ø≈øity
being our Ma≈øter) I digged holes in the earth, ≈øetting my poles at an equal di≈øtance, and nailing the broken boards of the Casks, Che≈øts, and Cabins, and ≈øuch like to them, making my door to the Seaward, and having covered the top, with Sail clothes ≈øtrain'd, and nail'd; I in the ≈øpace of a week had made a large Cabbin big enough to hold all our goods and our ≈øelves in it; I al≈øo placed our Hamocks for lodging, purpo≈øing (if it plea≈øed God to ≈øend any Ship that way) we might be tran≈øported home, but it never came to pa≈øs, the place, wherein we were (as I conceived) being much out of the way.

We having now lived in this manner full four moneths, and not ≈øo much as ≈øeeing or hearing of any wild people or of any of our own company, more then our ≈øelves (they being found now by experience to be all drowned) and the place as we after found, being a large I≈øland, and di≈øjoyned, and out of ≈øight of any other Land, was wholly uninhabited by any people, neither was there any hurtful bea≈øt to annoy us. But on the contrary, the Countrey ≈øo very plea≈øant, being always clothed with green, and full of plea≈øant fruits, and variety of Birds, ever warm, and never colder then in England in September: ≈øo that this place (had it the culture that skilful people might be≈øtow on it) would prove a Paradi≈øe.

The Woods afforded us a ≈øort of Nuts, as big as a large Apple, who≈øe kernil being plea≈øant and dry, we made u≈øe of in≈øtead of Bread, that Fowl before mentioned, and a ≈øort of Water-fowl like Ducks, and their Eggs, and a Bea≈øt about the ≈øize of a Goat, and almo≈øt ≈øuch a like Creature, which brought two young ones at a time, and that twice a year, of which the Low Lands and Woods were very full, being a very harmle≈øs Creature and tame, ≈øo that we could ea≈øily take and kill them: Fi≈øh al≈øo, e≈øpecially Shell-fi≈øh (which we could be≈øt come by) we had great ≈øtore of, ≈øo that in effect as to Food we wanted nothing; and thus, and by ≈øuch like helps, we continued ≈øix moneths, without any di≈øturbance or want.

Idlene≈øs and fulne≈øs of every thing begot in me a de≈øire
of enjoying the Women, beginning now to grow more familiar. I had per≈øwaded the two Maids to let me lie with them, which I did at fir≈øt in private, but after, cu≈øtome taking away ≈øhame (there being none but us) we did it more openly, as our Lu≈øt gave us liberty; afterwards my Ma≈øters Daughter was content al≈øo to do as we did; the truth is, they were all hand≈øome women, when they had clothes, and well ≈øhaped, feeding well. For we wanted no Food, and living idlely, and ≈øeeing us at liberty to do our wills, without hope of ever returning home made us thus bold: One of the fir≈øt of my Con≈øorts, with whom I fir≈øt accompanied (the talle≈øt and hand≈øome≈øt) proved pre≈øently with child, the ≈øecond was my Ma≈øters Daughter, and the other al≈øo not long after fell into the ≈øame condition: none now remaining but my Megro, who ≈øeeing what we did, longed al≈øo for her ≈øhare one night, I being a≈øleep, my Negro (with the con≈øent of others) got clo≈øe to me, thinking it being dark to begule me, but I awaking and feeling her, and perceiving who it was, yet willing to try the difference, ≈øatisfied my ≈øelf with her, as well as with one of the re≈øt; that night although the fir≈øt time, ≈øhe proved al≈øo with child, ≈øo that in the year of our being here, all my women were with child by me, and they all coming at different ≈øea≈øons, were a great help to one another.

The fir≈øt brought me a brave boy, my Ma≈øters Daughter was the younge≈øt ≈øhe brought me a Girl, ≈øo did the other Maid, who being ≈øomething fat ≈øped wor≈øe at her labour, the Negro had no pain at all, and brought me a fine white Girle, ≈øo I had one Boy, and three Girles: the Women were ≈øoon well again, and the two fir≈øt with child again, before the two la≈øt were brought to bed: My cu≈øtome being not to lie with any of them after they were with child, till other were ≈øo likewi≈øe; and not with the Black, at all after: ≈øhe was with child: which commonly was at the fir≈øt tiem, I lay with her, which was in the night and not el≈øe, my ≈øtomach would not ≈øerve me, although ≈øhe was one of the hand≈øome≈øt Blacks, I had ≈øeen, and her children as comely as any fo the re≈øt; we had no clothes for them, and therefore when they had ≈øuckt, we ≈øaid, them in M ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe to ≈øleep, and took no further care of them, for we knew, when they were gone more would come; the Women
never failing once a year at lea≈øt, and none of the Children (for all the hard≈øhip we put them to) were ever ≈øick; ≈øo that wanting now nothing but Cloathes, nor them much neither, other then for decency, the warmth of the Countrey and Cu≈øtome ≈øupplying that Defect, we were now well ≈øatisfied with our condition, our Family beginning to grow large, and there being nothing to hurt us, we many times lay abroad on Mo≈ø≈øey Banks, under the ≈øhelter of ≈øome Trees, or ≈øuch like (for having nothing el≈øe to do) I had made me ≈øeveral Arbors to ≈øleep in with my Women in the heat of the day, in the≈øe I and my Women pa≈ø≈øed the time away, they being never willing to be out of my company.

And having now no thought of ever returning home, as having re≈øolved and ≈øworn each to other, never to part or leave one another, or the place; having by my ≈øeveral Wives, forty ≈øeven Children, Boys and Girls, but mo≈øt Girls, and growing up apace, we were all of us very fle≈øhy, the Country ≈øo well agreeing with us, that we never ailed any thing; my Negro having had twelve, was the fir≈øt that left bearing, ≈øo I never medled with her more: My Ma≈øters Daughter (by whom I had mo≈øt Children, being the younge≈øt and hand≈øome≈øt) was mo≈øt fond of me, and I of her. Thus we lived for ≈øixteen years, till perceiving my elde≈øt Boy to mind the ordinary work of Nature, by ≈øeeing what we did, I gave him a Mate, and ≈øo I did to all the re≈øt, as fa≈øt as they grew up, and were capable: My Wives having left bearing, my children began to breed apace, ≈øo we were like to be a multitude; My fir≈øt Wife brought me thirteen Children, my ≈øecond ≈øeven, my Ma≈øters Daughter fifteen, and the Negro twelve, in all forty ≈øeven.

After we had lived there twenty two years, my Negro died ≈øuddenly, but I could not percive any thing that ailed her; mo≈øt of my children being grown, as fa≈øt as we married them, I ≈øent them and placed them over the River by them≈øelves ≈øeverally, becau≈øe we would not pe≈øter one another; and now they being all grown up, and gone, and married after our manner (≈øome two or three of the younge≈øt) for (growing my ≈øelf into years) I liked not the wanton annoyance of young company.

Thus having lived to the ≈øixtieth year of my age, and the fortieth of my coming thither, at which time I ≈øent for all of them to bring their children, and there were in number de≈øcended from me by the≈øe four Women, of my Children, Grand-children, & great Grand-children, five hundred ≈øixty five of both ≈øorts; I took off the Males of one Family, and married them to the Females of another, not letting any to marry their ≈øi≈øters, as we did formerly out of nece≈ø≈øity, ≈øo ble≈ø≈øing God for his Providence and goodne≈øs, I di≈ømi≈øt them, I having taught ≈øome of my Children to read formerly, for I had left ≈øtill the Bible, I charged it ≈øhould be read once a moneth at a general meeting: At la≈øt one of my Wives died being ≈øixty eighth years of age, which I buried in a place, ≈øet out on purpo≈øe, and within a year after another, ≈øo I had none now left but my Ma≈øters Daughter, and we lived together twelve years longer, at length ≈øhe died al≈øo, ≈øo I buried her al≈øo next the place where I purpo≈øed to be buried my ≈øelf, and the tall Maid my fir≈øt Wife next me on the other ≈øide, the Negro next without her, and the other Maid next my Ma≈øters Daughter. I had now nothing to mind, but the place whether I was to go, being very old, almo≈øt eighty years, I gave my Cabin and Furniture that was left to my elde≈øt ≈øon after my decea≈øe, who had married my elde≈øt Daughter by my beloved Wife, whom I made King and Governour of all the re≈øt: I informed them of the Manners of Europe, and charged them to remember the Chri≈øtian Religion, after the manner of them that ≈øpake the ≈øame Language, and to admit no other, if hereafter any ≈øhould come and find them out.

And now once for all, I ≈øummoned them to come to me, that I might number them, which I did, and found the e≈øtimate to contain in or about the eightieth year of my age, and the fifty ninth of my coming there; in all of all ≈øorts one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred eighty and nine. Thus praying God to multiply them, and ≈øend them the true light of the Go≈øpel, I la≈øt of all di≈ømi≈øt them: For, being now very old, and my ≈øight decayed, I could not expect to live long. I gave this Narration (written with my own hand) to my Elde≈øt Son, who now lived
with me, commanding him to keep it, and if any ≈øtrangers ≈øhould come hither by chance, to let them ≈øee it, and take a Copy of it if they would, that our name be not lo≈øt from off the earth. I gave this People (de≈øcended from me) the name of the ENGLISH PINES, George Pine being my name, and my Ma≈øters Daughters name Sarah Engli≈øh, my two other Wives were Mary Sparkes, and Elizabeth Trevor, ≈øo their ≈øeveral De≈øcendants are called the ENGLISH, the SPARKS, and the TREVORS, and the PHILLS, from the Chri≈øtian Name of the Negro, which was Phillippa, ≈øhe having no ≈øurname: And the general name of the whole the ENGLISH PINES; whom God ble≈ø≈øe with the dew of Heaven, and the fat of the Earth, AMEN,
